Title:
Morphological and molecular evidence for a new species of the
genus Melanochlamys Cheeseman, 1881 from the Bohai Sea, China
(Gastropoda: Heterobranchia)
Keywords:
Cephalaspidea, Aglajidae, sea slug, ABGD, male
reproductive organ
Abstract:
Increasing discoveries of new species of the genus
Melanochlamys Cheeseman, 1881 in recent years demonstrate that the
biodiversity of this group remains underestimated. Recently, several
aglajid sea slugs were collected from Laizhou Bay, Shandong Province,
China. Morphological observation of their external and internal anatomy
revealed that they represent an undescribed species that belong to genus
Melanochlamys. This new species, Melanochlamys aquilina sp. nov., is
closely related to Melanochlamys fukudai Cooke, Hanson, Hirano,
Ornelas-Gatdula, Gosliner, Chernyshev & Vald√©s, 2014 in body size
and dark external coloration, but can be differentiated from the latter
by features of both shell and male reproductive organ. Phylogenetic
analyses of two mitochondrial (COI, 16S rRNA) and a nuclear (H3) gene
using Bayesian inference, maximum likelihood, and species delimitation
analysis also support the separation of Melanochlamys aquilina sp. nov.
from its related congeners. The molecular analysis indicates a close
evolutionarily relationship between Melanochlamys aquilina sp. nov. and
M. fukudai, a species from Japan, and that their divergence time may
happened in a relatively short historical period, possibly no more than
0.8 My.
